body:
> +1 to what @matthiasblaesing said, and as per mailing list conversation, if we can move to Maven Central we should consider publishing as NBMs via plugin portal (and remove from third-party UC) so that IDE updates aren't needed to update nb-javac.

Let me get back to you all with if and how we can do this .
Approved, thanks for getting this done Akshay
This is the latest nb-javac to support JDK 15 features along for NB 12.2

Requested review from Eric.  I'm dubious about the instructions.  Would have thought mirroring how the source release handles this might be better?  eg. netbeansrelease.properties in nbbuild/  If existence of that file doesn't stop request for the release json (haven't checked that yet) that sounds like an error that needs fixing anyway?!

EDIT : removed -1 because it's the instructions in the description, not the commits, that may need addressing.
@lkishalmi can you please add the milestone as 12.2 please?

The change looks fine to me.

Regarding publishing on Plugin Portal - not sure if that's desirable (at least unless we can have a separate plugin for every NetBeans release). As happened during the 11 timeframe (with .1 and .2 or .2 and .3, I don't recall), a newer version of NetBeans may require nb-javac that is incompatible with the newer version of NetBeans. So having a single AUC with a single version of nb-javac for both such versions may not be possible.

Hi @matthiasblaesing 
 maybe we could add a step to download-all-extbins to download the json file in correct place to avoid the wget phase.  
AFAIK download-all-extbins is not used in "standard build".

It make me think that step 3 -D parameters  is a hack as json file should be detected and used.

Maybe the following code on build.xml in nbbuild line 112 can avoid all the json mess.

```
 <!-- get all json info we have on apache gitbox  -->
    <property name="metabuild.releasejson" value="${nb_all}/nbbuild/build/netbeansrelease.json"/>
    <condition property="metabuild.jsonurl" value="https://gitbox.apache.org/repos/asf?p=netbeans-jenkins-lib.git;a=blob_plain;f=meta/netbeansrelease.json">
        <not>
            <isset property="metabuild.jsonurl"/>
        </not>
    </condition>
    <condition property="needjson">
        <not>
            <available file="${metabuild.releasejson}" />
        </not>
    </condition>
    <sequential if:set="needjson" >
        <configureproxy connectTo="${metabuild.jsonurl}" hostProperty="proxyHost" portProperty="proxyPort"/>
        <setproxy proxyhost="${proxyHost}" proxyPort="${proxyPort}"/>
        <get dest="${metabuild.releasejson}" skipexisting="false" src="${metabuild.jsonurl}" />     
    </sequential>
    <!-- read info from gitinfo.properties , if present in source bundle copy gitinfo-->
```

EDIT to add the xml code

I'm not sure for plugin portal bug having nb-javac on maven central instead of netbeans.osuosl.org make easier to use for Mavenized NetBeans. 

By the way, you can't use org.netbeans groupId as it's locked by Apache NetBeans. 
But lots of groupId at com.oracle exists should be possible to add one specific like com.oracle.nbtooling and also maybe there is a global Oracle way to publish. Oracle jdbc are since a year or two in maven central

@lahodaj yes, that's true, but we do now have unique plugin URLs for each release, which was half the problem. Unfortunately, 12.1 still ends up forwarded to the plugin catalog for 12.0 on the portal itself.  So we would need to fix that for this to happen - a good step forward, but probably not a viable idea for 12.2 at this time.

ping @sdedic @jlahoda Your comment have been incorporated. Can we finish this?
CC: @lkishalmi

@neilcsmith-net @ebarboni my target was enabling build offline - the procedure was just to show, that it can be successfully done, without to much fuzz. You can broaden the scope, but it was not intended to be.

The approach to download the json file to some "build" directory will not work. `ant clean` will clean the build directory and your offline buildability is gone.
For me this is ok to merge
Right, sorry. Oddly enough, that was the one part of the patch that didn't just apply. Just a moment while I take care of that.

There you go. Just a random suggestion, is it possible for you to override the default formatting settings on the projects to use spaces instead of tabs? I generally use tabs and find myself needing to use an external editor if I don't want to change that setting since tabs always get inserted.

I think we should consider pulling some of this into a separate target with conditional?

Is there any need for the json file if `netbeansrelease.properties` exists in `build`?  Not sure a source release build should ever need to touch the json file either.

Perhaps move copy earlier, and only trigger target downloading and parsing json if `netbeansrelease.properties` doesn't already exist?
Lets see what comes from this - if this backfires it is trivial to revert.

I see the problem, that global state (binaries cache) influences the build. If you are not aware of the file, rebuilding netbeans for a newer tag will not yield the same result. Even running "git clean -f -x -d" will not clean that up.

I also think a separate target would be good - then it would be trivial to combine `download-all-extbins` and this task.
Thank you for the review. Let's get this in.

I modified this patch to turn off the new behavior by default, enabled only via system property. That should make it safer to merge. Whether this should be promoted to a GUI option is another question.
Good call with the system property. That prevents the patch from being lost, and shows more clearly what the difference in behavior is.

@eirikbakke if you can spare a bit of time, please try running with this patch with and without `-J-Dorg.netbeans.modules.java.source.usages.BuildArtifactMapperImpl.COMPARE_TIMESTAMPS=true` to verify that it continues to solve your CoS issues. (Yes the index can still get corrupted, leading to breakage of editor features.)
Will do.
Looks good to me.

I try to alter the process, but in fact download-all-extbins hide a lot in the antsrc and is offline because it check the cache in java.

Trying to embed the json in release bundle. 
If I'm right
If found use it. If you build a release you will stay with the release you have.

On a normal dev you will be on master by default, you may miss new release tag for javadoc construction (version navigation).
If you try do ant -metabuild.branch=releaseXXX (not in your local json)  ant will tell: 
 No Release Information found for branch releaseXXX, update json file section with ant -Dneedjsondownload=true

Hope it's better workflow
I hope merged early enough to get some Java 15 feedback in the 12.2 cycle.
Do we know why the timeouts happen in the first place?
I've addressed and all the comments regarding formatting @junichi11. Squashed as well. Waiting for merge.
Thank you for addressing all the comments, approved. Please resolve the conflicts in master branch as pointed by @lkishalmi
@lahodaj Thanks for reviewing and giving the good comments. I'll address all these.
@lkishalmi  I've resolve the conflict with master. But after resolving I had to merge master into this branch, so now I can't rebase my local branch and squash the commits.

I was writing HTML and JavasScript support in NetBeans probably more than for three years. What Svata is suggesting and doing was on my TODO list for long time, but as usually there were still other priorities. So I agree with Svata's PR and I'm supporting him to finish splitting the indexing from editor.
Updated original commits with missing licenses (for the new module).
Some description would be good, maybe a JIRA ticket as well. The change seems to be quite extensive.

Impressive amount of work! Thank you for that!
I have a naive question. Would it fix the Java SE cluster dependency on the HTML5 cluster or that would be another story?

> Impressive amount of work! Thank you for that!
> I have a naive question. Would it fix the Java SE cluster dependency on the HTML5 cluster or that would be another story?

Not sure, it wasn't (yet) the primary goal; but I've tried to reduce dependencies from java and javascript to HTML. Can you give an example of the offending dependency ? Might be easier to get rid of it now.

Ok, the patch looks clean, it is simple enough to be considered trivial (parameter passing), Emilian is an apache committer, unittests come back clean. I tested a build and a timestamp was reported from jarsigner after I build with a tsaurl. So lets get this in.
It would be good to add the `extide/gradle` module in Travis config to allow Travis run the tests

hectorespert web-flow
hectorespert web-flow
Today I updated to most recent master and my build succeeded (instead of failing in `javaee.wildfly` module). Very nice surprise. Thank you.
Just remove the empty layer.xml I've checked out this PR removed the layer.xml, it still builds fine. Then we can finally merge this.

> Just remove the empty layer.xml I've checked out this PR removed the layer.xml, it still builds fine. Then we can finally merge this.

I will do this, but i think it will build fine, but it won't run when you try to install the plugin.
@hectorespert That's valid as actually this one makes some test fail.
Added a note in apichanges and incremented spec version. I also took into account all the wizards from the Java category, but not sure how I can enhance arch.xml.
It seems this broke maven projects: https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/NETBEANS/issues/NETBEANS-4885

Looks sane to me. We might have to revisit this later, but I think this is a good improvement, the new libraries are a sane subset, the implementation does not touch API, so can be improved later.

Lets get this in.

@MasterEx thank you for your contribution. 

The merge assumes, that you are aware of the license header and thus acknowledge, that you donate the code to the ASF. If that is not acceptable, please indicate so, the merge will need to be reverted then.

> @MasterEx thank you for your contribution.
> 
> The merge assumes, that you are aware of the license header and thus acknowledge, that you donate the code to the ASF. If that is not acceptable, please indicate so, the merge will need to be reverted then.

Hi @matthiasblaesing, thank you for your time and guidance! Sure, I acknowledge my donation of the code to the ASF.

```
Unapproved license in 2 file(s) 
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/tree/master/enterprise/j2ee.clientproject/src/org/netbeans/modules/j2ee/clientproject/ui/resources/application-client-8.xml
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/tree/master/enterprise/j2ee.dd/src/org/netbeans/modules/j2ee/dd/impl/resources/connector_1_6.xsd
```

@MKuettner One technicality before we can merge this--could you ensure that the email address you want associated with this commit is visible on your Github profile (as a "public email" in the "profile" section of your settings)?

(When we merge the commits into the NetBeans codebase, they will become a single commit with author information taken from your github profile.)
Add missing files to licenseinfo.xml in j2ee.clientproject module and squashed commits.
As it is approved and green, now it is merged.
Seems to be trivial enough. Merging.

```
/home/travis/build/apache/netbeans/scratch/nbbuild/build.xml:2253: Failed Rat test(s):
Unapproved license in 1 file(s) 
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/tree/master/nbbuild/netbeansrelease.json
```
If I understand correctly, this will remove code completion for javascript, if the corresponding library is in node_modules? Or what I'm missing?

@matthiasblaesing unfortunately you are right. But what speaks against it is the following case:

I have 5 - 6 Web projects open (next to a lot of others, web independent projects).
One project is the biggest, that I'm working on, it is from my company. The node_modules folder has 115.605 files and 18.964 folders. The node_modules folder is 963 mb big. It is a mono repo with nrwl-nx - Angular application. After I removed the node_modules from the ignored files pattern, NetBeans started indexing. This project, needed round about 1h to finish and the web projects needed round about 1 more hour. So all in all it ~ 2h for indexing/background scanning the node_modules folder. Which seems waaaaaay to long.

My environment is a Surface Laptop 3, Windows 10, latest version with an i7, 16GB RAM and a M2 SSD. Afaik, not even Windows need that much time to indexing 100k files. I know this is another case but there is also another application called everything: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Everything_(software) It took round about 30s - 1m to index the whole SSD with 3.638.195 files on it. It is written in C/C++ and assembler. Just to let you know, that I don't understand, why NetBeans took so long so as you see it gets faster. Btw Windows Defender is disabled, so this can't be the problem.

So long story short, whether there is possible to be as fast as the everything tool, which would be pretty awesome in any case and second, if not possible my solution for indexing the node_modules would be to read out all packages from the package.json and bower.json, that should be fast enough I guess. Also, indexing all modules, that are used by require() and the ES 6 modules with import etc. So that would be a good improvement to still have code completion for all imported modules and maybe sub modules like incrementialy index.

Is one of those solutions possible? IMHO, it is not needed to index all files in node_modules. Or someone knows how VS Code and WebStorm does it. WebStorm is also fast enough for my point of view. It just needed ~2min to index the company project which is quite good.

@Chris2011 so this is a big hammer that helps you, but might be a problem for "normal" JS users. 

I can explain why indexing in netbeans is slow: Because the JS indexer tries to deal with the mess, that is the JS ecosystem. The JS files are parsed in context and that is a dramatic slowdown.

By your description your "fix" basicly breaks all index based support for every JS project, that uses npm to manage its dependencies.  The only support that is retained is typescript completion, as that is handled by the typescript language server.

Given, that the side effect described above this is a -1 for me.

Edit: added personal judgement.

what is a "normal" js user? If you use npm you install your dep and it installs more deps, etc. The other 4 projects are not that big but still have > 20k files inside of it and those are normal JS projects created with Vue CLI or Angular CLI etc. So some other people complained about that in Stack Overflow too "How can I prevent node_modules from indexing in NetBeans". And as I said, why does WebStorm not has this problem with JS parsing?

> I can explain why indexing in netbeans is slow: Because the JS indexer tries to deal with the mess, that is the JS ecosystem. The JS files are parsed in context and that is a dramatic slowdown.

Just in NetBeans, not in any other major IDEs/Editor. I tried it couple of minutes ago with WebStorm, the result is significant and this is what I expect for NetBeans too. WebStorm also indexes the node_modules folder as I can see, when I open a web project, what my company project was. So as I understand it right, just the JS parser in NetBeans is slow and not a JS parser in general.

Anyway, thx for the hint with the indexing we can revert it, but we need a solution for that. Here again:

* Make the JS paraser as fast as possible to make it comparable with other major IDEs. 2h is to long and it is even possible.
* Just index the packages from the package.json and bower.json because those are the packages that are used via require() and import
* Make the indexing in NetBeans as fast as possible and take a look into the everything tool.

Yes I can understand that not just indexing, but also parsing is done here. So everything could be just a hint for indexing and not for parsing.
So everyne who uses npm and a major cli to create a project is just a "normal" JS user BTW. Also we have business cases and not business cases. Or maybe enterprise applications and not so enterprise.

I wonder how parallel the indexer is. I know we have multithreading there
but I forgot how much: an i7 means 8 threads at least.

It would be very cool to have pre-computed indexes which are just
downloaded for a node module. Then there's no CPU waste, just bandwidth.

In an alternate universe it would be very cool to look into the indexing
infra and decouple it a bit, maybe throw it to a separate process, etc.
Lots of indexing problems with other languages too.

--emi

I need to revert this change. You need to file a new PR. I'm sorry for the inconveniences.

The problem is that the row count of the JTable is updated, _after_ tableDataChanged is reached. So the method reads the row count at the wrong moment. A fix needs to ensure all pending events have happened before the _read_ is done. The read is backingTable.getRowCount() - if that is invoked directly and only the fireTableDataChanged is dispatched into the invokeLater, you are still reading the wrong value.

The whole method body of tableDataChanged most be moved into the invokeLater.
